awd_titl_txt: Support for the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR
awd_abstract_narration:
With National Science Foundation support the Archaeometry Laboratory the University of Missouri Research Reactor Center (MURR) will continue to serve as the most comprehensive US-based laboratory dedicated to chemical characterization studies of archaeological materials. The analytical techniques available include neutron activation analysis (NAA), inductively-coupled-plasma mass-spectrometry (ICP-MS) of solutions using high resolution, quadrupole, and multicollector instruments, laser ablation ICP-MS (LA-ICP-MS), and X-ray fluorescence (XRF). These techniques permit the quantification of major, minor and trace elements simultaneously and with a high degree of accuracy and precision in a wide range of archaeological materials. The MURR laboratory also plays an important role in training students in the analytical techniques for application to specific archaeological questions. Frequently, archaeology students are invited to spend time at MURR where they are taught a variety of methods for interpreting archaeological data and have direct access to the large compositional databases containing more than 130,000 previous analyses of pottery, obsidian, basalt, and chert. Online access to these databases is continuing to be developed and improved for integration with databases from other laboratories. Laboratory staff and students are also involved in efforts to rescue compositional databases from laboratories no longer in operation. The ceramic databases in many parts of the world have reached a sufficient size to allow regional syntheses that examine large-scale patterns of ceramic production, use and exchange.

In addition to continued support of student and senior archaeology research projects, funding helps support the development of calibration standards and analytical procedures that facilitate the integration of data from multiple analytical techniques (e.g., INAA, ICP-MS, XRF). These efforts will benefit both new and mature analytical programs involved in archaeometric compositional analysis research. Ferguson and Glascock continue to oversee the development and application of LA-ICP-MS to archaeological materials and facilitate the development of portable-XRF for archaeometric research. The broader impacts of this work includes the elemental data generated in collaboration with colleagues and students that will be used to address important topics related to human and social dynamics of prehistoric peoples and societies, such as, mobility patterns and migrations of people, cultural responses to conflict and stress, community social organization, the development of craft production and specialization, and the creation and maintenance of social boundaries and identity.

por.por_cntn:
The project continues support of a long-term commitment by the Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR to promote collaborative research between archaeologists, chemists, and others interested in archaeological science. Funds provided by the NSF, along with support from the University of Missouri, enable lowering the analytical costs for faculty and graduate student researchers in the field of archaeology. These analytical methods can be used to determine the geological sources of artifacts, to study trade/exchange networks and other interactions between people and places, to research possible migration of ancient human populations, and to investigate the development of ancient technologies. 

The Archaeometry Laboratory is unique in that we are the only laboratory in the world making access to three of the most powerful analytical techniques (NAA, XRF, and ICP-MS) possible for archaeologists. As a result of the techniques available and the funding support from NSF, research projects involving the large numbers of samples often required to address significant archaeological questions are being investigated.

In addition to our efforts to make chemical analysis more affordable, the Archaeometry Laboratory is involved in training visiting researchers and students from the University of Missouri and other academic institutions concerning research design, sample preparation, and interpretation of the chemical data obtained from analysis of archaeological samples.  Projects submitted to the Archaeometry laboratory undergo an internal and external review to ensure proper integration of research questions, sample design, and analytical techniques.

During the three-year grant period, more than 110 faculty and graduate students submitted over 20,000 archaeological samples to the Archaeometry Laboratory for investigation by one or more of the available analytical techniques. This work has produced more than 80 publications as either journal articles or book chapters, and supported more than 20 new graduate theses in anthropology, archaeology, geoscience, and chemistry. The total number of archaeological samples in our geochemical database now exceeds 170,000.  The majority of these data are available for use by archaeologists and other researchers from around the world.

Some of the broader impacts of NSF support to the Archaeometry Laboratory include raising the profile of archaeological science through public lectures and direct involvement of undergraduate and graduate students from the University of Missouri and other institutions in the application of analytical techniques to archaeological science.  This training is preparing students for careers in archaeology, chemistry, forensic science, cultural resource management and other disciplines where collaborations across disciplines are important.  Finally, the Archaeometry Laboratory is better preparing undergraduates in these disciplines for advanced graduate work.  The Archaeometry Laboratory at MURR continues to provide arguably the greatest publication to cost ratio of any long-term program funded by NSF, and these research results continue to further greater understanding of the natural world and the role of humans in it – both past and present.
